Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-CalARP program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, BWC Tank Farm Mixer has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-CalARP related activities. 



1.1 BWC Tank Farm Mixer, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that BWC Tank Farm Mixer has developed their unified RMP-CalARP Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)

20% Aqueous Ammonia           Aqueous Ammonia                 49,000



Our RMP-CalARP program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. 



Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the RMP regulation and designed to satisfy all CalARP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3.

Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-CalARP program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Buttonwillow Warehouse Company Tank Farm Mixer operates a fertilizer storage, distribution, and mixing facility in Buttonwillow, CA. A 20% aqueous ammonia solution is utilized at the facility as required for producing ammoniated zinc. 



1.2.2 Facility Location



Buttonwillow Warehouse Company Tank Farm Mixer is located at 125 Front Street, Buttonwillow, CA 93206. The latitude and longitude of the tank farm mixer is 35.398346, -119.470706. The facility is located approximately 4 miles west of Interstate Highway 5, surrounded by the city of Buttonwillow to the north and agricultural land to the west, east, and south.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Buttonwillow Warehouse Company Tank Farm Mixer is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Buttonwillow Warehouse Company Tank Farm Mixer has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



1.2.3 Description of Covered Process



At Buttonwillow Warehouse Company Tank Farm Mixer, the 20% aqueous ammonia solution is stored in a portable poly tank and pumped to the 2,500 gallon mixer where it is mixed with zinc powder and water to form ammoniated zinc. During the mixing process, the 20% aqueous ammonia solution is consumed by the chemical reactions which occur.



Process Chemistry



Aqueous ammonia is utilized at the Warehouse Tank Mixer as a reactant in

a chemical process that produces an intermediate product for fertilizer manufacturing. The aqueous ammonia is reacted with water and zinc powder in the following reaction.



The water and aqueous ammonia are mixed in solution and then the zinc powder is added.



2(NH3) (aq) + 2H2O (l) + Zn(2+) (aq)



The ammonia molecule deprotonates the water and forms ammonium ions, NH4(+), and hydroxide, OH(-)



2NH4(+) (aq) + 2OH(-) (aq) + Zn(2+) (s) 



The hydroxide ions bond to the Zn(2+) ion, and form Zinc(II)Hydroxide, Zn(OH)2. The Zinc(II)Hydroxide is not soluble in water and precipitates out of solution; making the solution thicken and turn white.



2NH4(+) (aq) + Zn(OH)2 (s)



When the above reaction is complete, more aqueous ammonia and water are added until the concentration of ammonia is quadruple that of the Zinc(II)Hydroxide. This excess ammonia shares electrons with the zinc that simultaneously fill the outermost, bonding electron shell of the zinc and the nitrogen. This breaks the bond between the Zn and the two hydroxyl groups; causing them to separate and form hydroxide ions, OH(-).



4NH3 (aq) + Zn(OH)2 (s) → 4NH3(+) (aq) + Zn(2-) + 2OH(-)



Finally, the ammonia molecules combine with the zinc and form a complex ion with a +2 charge overall. The charges within the complex ion, -2 on the Zn and +1 on each NH3 molecule, make the molecule polar, meaning that it has localized areas of both positive and negative charge, and since water is also polar, the ion is soluble and dissolves in solution.



4NH3 (aq) + Zn(2+) → [Zn(NH3)4](2+) + 2OH(-)



The ammoniated zinc that is formed is the chemical intermediate that is utilized in fertilizer manufacturing, and the solution is filtered to remove impurities and then stored until use.

Safety Systems



2,500 Gallon Mixing Tank Control Panel



The 2,500 Gallon Mixing Tank has a control panel which starts and stops the pumps and conveyor associated with the tank.



Scale



The 2,500 Gallon Mixing Tan

k is equipped with a scale which is critical to the mixing operation. The scale is continuously monitored by the mixing operator. Pumps are turned on and off based on the scale readings and the blend sheet that is being followed.



Isolation Valves



Both the 6,500 gallon storage tank and the 1,000 gallon portable tanks are equipped with isolation valves which can be used to stop a transfer process if a pump cannot be controlled.



Fire Extinguisher



A fire extinguisher is located near the control panel of the 2,500 Gallon Mixing Tank Control Panel.



Emergency Eyewash and Shower Station



The emergency eyewash and shower station has been installed in close proximity to the 2,500 Gallon Mixing Tank.



Main Gas Shut-Off



The main gas shut-off is located to the east of the 2,500 Gallon Mixing Tank and protected by a concrete barrier.



Main Water Shut-Off



The main water shut-off is located north-west of the Tank Farm along the railroad track.



Main Electrical Shut-Off



The main electrical shut off is located south of the mixing control panel.



Signage



The 6,500 Gallon Storage Tank is equipped with a vendor supplied label when 20% aqueous ammonia solution is stored inside the tank.



Wind Sock



A wind sock has been installed near the mixer. Employees have been instructed to consider the wind direction when evacuating during an ammonia release.



1.2.4 Process Classification



The 20% aqueous ammonia system at Buttonwillow Warehouse Company Tank Farm Mixer consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the 20% aqueous ammonia system at Buttonwillow Warehouse Company Tank Farm Mixer is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of aqueous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, suc

h as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



BWC Tank Farm Mixer has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the 20% aqueous ammonia process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



BWC Tank Farm Mixer has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



BWC Tank Farm Mixer's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



BWC Tank Farm Mixer has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, BWC Tank Farm Mixer continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-CalARP prog

ram. This has improved BWC Tank Farm Mixer's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-CalARP related events so that BWC Tank Farm Mixer's management team can ensure that the RMP-CalARP program is being implemented.



BWC Tank Farm Mixer has implemented all aspects of the RMP-CalARP program. When a RMP-CalARP program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, BWC Tank Farm Mixer has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-CalARP program implementation.



For the future, BWC Tank Farm Mixer now thinks of the RMP-CalARP program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for BWC Tank Farm Mixer employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-CalARP program BWC Tank Farm Mixer will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
